We answer call lights and assist with toileting. We also are to help code patients by obtaining the crash cart and starting compressions, however we get paid very little though we take on many job titles and responsibilities. We also get beds ready for new admits to our floor and we get floated to different floors constantly.

review_title: Not horrible and definitely not great
pros: Okay salary, okay benefits, retirement options available, and mostly friendly co-workers.
cons: New management with no experience, education, overall background in mental health calling the shots, made caseloads unreasonably high, required intake for new patients to be scheduled on a weekly rolling basis that was unreasonable when you already have a full caseload and nowhere to schedule a new patient. New management also micromanaged therapists, put on a facade that new management was going to be helpful and the individual is fair. However, the new management knew nothing about the field of mental health, began reinforcing petty policies such as prohibition of wearing jeans to work (it was only on a Friday) and no longer allowing employees to flex time without knowledge until the employee found out repercussions were already taken for having done so. New management obviously motivated to move up the hierarchy of management at Henry Ford instead of focusing on what may be best and/or helpful to the therapists to effectively perform their jobs. New management took over therapist schedules and overloaded caseloads with no consideration of the negative affect (severe stress) on the therapists. New management failed to understand that overloading a therapist caseload and schedule decreases the quality of treatment provided to the patients which is ultimately unfair to the patients.

review_title: Great workplace for a part time student in the medical field or related fields.
pros:
- Good communication & work atmosphere with co-workers and staff members.
- Great training opportunities and certification avenues available should you want to peruse other jobs in the medical field.
- Awesome benefit plans with reasonable pay, flexible schedules, and time off.
cons:
- Some shifts tend to have long hours and workload tends to be high, yet variable, and there always seems to be some sort of short staffing (as usual with the medical industry).

- Tele sitter position requires consistent rational thinking, swift communication with the basic understanding of medical jargons, and solid observation skills applied over the whole shift. 

- The Tele sitter position is not meant for those that get jittery focusing on a screen for long periods of time, and is definitely more of a mental job over a physical one.

job_title: Nurse Assistant in Clinton Township, MI
pros: My coworkers on my unit were pleasant; 3- 12 hour shifts a week are great for work/life balance.
cons:
Pay, Management, Workload, Long Hours, Disrespect from patients, staff, and management.

Nursing Assistants, and nurses, are treated very poorly at Henry Ford. There is no Union, and Henry Ford will not stand up for you if you make a mistake due to being overworked. There is a vast staffing issue , and they are not trying to hire more NAs and RNs to help.

 I was responsible for 20-30 patients when the normal amount was 8-10. I didn’t receive any help from NAs or RNs.

Eventually I started having meetings with upper level executives to discuss the harsh working conditions and abymal pay. They did nothing for us. 

If you have another job offer, go somewhere else. The starting pay for a nursing assistant is $15, that pay is the same for other ancillary staff: housekeeping, transport, registration, HUCs, etc.

Don’t kill yourself for $15.

job_title: Contact Center Advocate in Detroit, MI
pros: Awesome working environment with very friendly supervisors. Henry Ford is very big on the "career progression ladder." They even mention it in the first interview that there are so many outlets they want you to take if you get the chance. Very good job to get your foot in the door, especially if you are planning a career in the health field. They are constantly trying to boost moral with weird special holidays like "national popcorn day" and everyone gets free popcorn. Everyone is willing to help each other out.
cons: Taking calls all day long can become a bit exhausting- very high turn around rate so constantly getting new co-workers. Would prefer a more stable environment.

job_title: Registered Nurse in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Quiet neighborhood. Nice decor.
cons: This campus hires, facilitates, and nourishes discriminatory minded, leadership. Any benefits they receive from the government should be taken away. I’m sure that they must have dozens of EEOC complaints for race based discrimination. Racist whites move up the ladder rather quickly and then systematically bully, and harrass black employees to a point where black employees quit from the stress of the racist harassment from management. HR is a joke because they allow any and all ridiculous write-ups on black employees. I watched while a racist white manager told some Filipino nurses speaking in Tagalog to speak English and don’t talk around her if she can’t understand what they’re saying. She went on to tell her racist white nurse friends how she hates people who don’t speak English. This campus is crazy! Diversity and inclusion are not apart of the mission here! They only hire black people to meet their quota, then they make the jobs and lives of those black people so unbearable, that they quit! If they don’t quit, they start a ridiculous paper trail to ultimately have them fired!  There needs to be an undercover investigation done on all units in this campus! Then it needs to lose all federal program funding!

review_title: You will learn a lot about how to handle tough politics
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Detroit, MI
pros:
Fast pace, constant change, and lots room to do interesting things if you thrive in chaos.
A great place for a self starter with outstanding political and social skills.
cons:
Management tries very hard but, is in a constant state of chaos. They are undertrained and suffer from overwork and high stress. Most of this is due to their poor organizational and time management skills. 
This unfortunately reflects back to employees as poor leadership, unprofessional behavior, indecisiveness, and very little capability to support their employees.
on the cost cutting. Don't expect a raise
If your not good at office politics don't come here, you will not survive!

pros: The people at HFHS are wonderful. It is the most friendly and collaborative place I've worked. I knew I would miss it, but I didn't know how much. Nancy is a fantastic leader and is so accessible and friendly. They cleared out unnecessary levels of middle management years ago. This is the health system I would turn to if I had a serious illness. Research is top notch. A wonderful corporate environment and very generous Combined Time Off program, even with some cuts in it over the years. A very compassionate and caring place to work.
cons: The only reasons I had to leave: low salary for skills, lack of opportunity for advancement in my field. It isn't their fault they are financially strapped though. National health care, if not struck down, should help a lot.

review_title: This is the best company Ive ever worked for
pros: Diversity across all spectrums is point of pride here. Despite the differences in employee's race, national origin, sexual orientation, etc, we all smile at each other, work well together and respect patients. I smile every time I walk into the building to come to work and this is the only company Ive worked for where I feel that everybody else is smiling when they come into work too. Upward movement is easy here, and management WANTS to see you succeed and grow. Daily communications by upper management to inform nursing staff of things they need to work on, and things they should be praised for.
cons: The pay here is not as competitive as other hospital systems in the area. Another thing I do not like is that nursing staff is required to work the night shift first until a day shift position becomes available. Which means, you may be working the night shift for months or years before you can move to days. Parking can be confusing as the lots we have to use change regularly.

pros: Great pay. Amazing coworkers. Tons of amazing experience. Perfect for a new graduate nurse.
cons: Absolutely no advancement. Prior to transferring units within the hospital, even if all interviewing went well, the managers from this potential new unit contact your current manager. This discussion is the deciding factor of if you can transfer units. The management, if they really like you or the unit is short staffed, will say whatever it takes to keep you on their own unit. I tried transferring numerous times to my dream unit, the management absolutely loved me. When asked about why my transfer was denied I was told that my manager was short staffed at this time, all 5 times over the course of 2 years although we were overstaffed. I had to officially quit then re-apply to be properly considered. This has occurred to several of my coworkers as well.

review_title: Company really cares about their employees, Good work/life balance, Learn a lot, work hard, not such great pay
pros: Company really cares about all of their their employees.  You will learn a lot in HR and work really hard.  HR is segregated by various departments so experience can be limiting if you are not able to move around.  Work/life balance is what has kept me, my experience has been great.  I am glad I work for HFHS, my overall experience has been wonderful.
cons: Room for advancement: HR should be set up with multiple levels within a job so there is room to grow but it's not.  Compensation is currently below market but increases are expected in 2015.  Heard many complaints that HR is understaffed and positions are hard to fill.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Wyandotte, MI
pros: Overall I have had a fairly good experience with them.
cons: I have personally used this many times in my career so far, however as of late I find that the individual listed as a manager on the front poster, is sorely lacking in her managerial skills. The last few times I have been there and she was there I have overheard her asking the other employees how to do things. Now I would completely understand that if it was a student or someone new, but I know she has been there for quite some time now. Overhearing her the last few times has caused me to lose faith in her abilities, and she has also been very curt to some of her employees.

review_title: A monopoly on health care in Jackson
pros: Free employee parking, many good staff members at the level of patient service.
cons: Very top heavy organizational structure with extremely high salaries for top management. In spite of their high salaries, they expend an inordinate amount of millions on consultants coming in to tell them how to save more money. The majority of these consultants have in fact created chaos and made the care of patients more difficult and more costly. It is unclear why such highly paid health care "professionals" need the assistance of consultants. Perhaps the executive level is so deficient that they should be replaced with actual professionals?

pros: Moderate level of name prestige.  Reasonably stable employment.  Excellent opportunity to learn new skills, because the 100+ year old building and equipment is in constant need of repair and upgrading.
cons:
No equity within most departments, many have HFH employees working side-by-side with contract employees performing identical job descriptions, but woefully diverse job stability,  pay rates, and benefits.  Many patient support areas have contract managers with oversight of HFH employees.  This structure creates a great deal of animosity within departments and results in very low morale in many areas.

The only meaningful communication is through gossip and rumors.  Upper management does little to even attempt to communicate with front-line managers and it only get worse further down the food chain.

Upper management holds  tyrannical, myopic reins over lower level management and is closed to new ideas.

No work - life balance.  Front line managers are expected to be available 24-7-365,  60+ hour work weeks are common.  Phone calls at 1 or 2 am are a regular occurance.

Good ol' boy network at it's best.  Many HFH managers are underqualifed for their positions, but well-received by upper management.

pros: There are none, they pay their employees the lowest wages possible. They do not care about their employees, my hospital closed and I was told I could collect unemployment benefits, well they lied I worked there for several years and lost my job and my house because henry ford is dishonest with their employees and so is nancy the CEO I tried contacting her several times to have her explain why they lied to all their employees that lost their jobs being able to collect unemployment and then denying us
cons: Taking a huge pay cut, no raises, no bonuses, horrible management, no rewards for being a top performing employee, all around dishonest business, I would never set foot in a henry ford facility even if I was on my death bed, I do not trust the health system and have made sure none of my family or friends go there for healthcare. The doctors do not care about patients they only want their paycheck and your lucky if they give you five min of their time after you've beer waiting to see them for several hours

pros: The only reason I work for Henry Ford Health System is because I get my title of Art Therapist. I started this job doing what I am trained to do, use art to work with patients with a mental disorder.
cons:
Expensive and useless health benefits that mandate service from Henry Ford doctors only and do not cover emergency or unscheduled office visits.
Low pay and raises never occur even if you earned one by HR requirements. 
Time clock that forces you to clock in/out exactly at your scheduled time, absolutely no acceptions.
Forced use of vacation time (that is earned as 3 hrs per pay period) verses the choice of unpaid or paid. 
In order to qualify for medical leave (such as when I had my son), you have to have minimum of 2wks worth of vacation time otherwise you do not get paid medical leave.

review_title: New community in affluent area of Michigan.
job_title: Nurse Practitioner in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: I began working here before hospital opened as part of leadership team, hiring staff for critical care units. Exciting to get new hospital up and running. Mission to serve the community taking health and healing beyond the boundaries of imagination. Management listens to the employees and takes their ideas seriously. Employees are very focused on serving the patients and families well, providing the best care possible. Doctors, nurses, and other allied health employees work collaboratively as a team for the benefit of the patients.
cons: Undergoing budget cuts due to uncertainty about government insurance reimbursement.  Company is cutting services that can make a big difference in patient and family satisfaction and quality of life for those patients at end of life.

review_title: Highly recommended as a place to work.
pros: Good compensation and benefits.  A place you would be proud to work for.  Excellent health care providers and support staff.  I can't obviously speak for everybody as the system is huge but our department head was a great leader.  Staff felt supported at all times.  Good vision to make the department sucessful.
cons: Detroit is a city that is failing which makes working and living there a challenge.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Detroit, MI
pros: Flexible work schedule and the atmosphere throughout the hospital is warm and friendly.  After completing one year in your new position, it is easy to acquire other positions throughout the hospital.
cons: The salary is not compatible with other institutions.  Parking for employees at the Detroit site  may hinder one from reporting on time due to employees required to take a shuttle to work. There is always a long line of people.  The wait time can not be calculated. Employees get docked and written up due to unreliable transportation services.

pros: Great benefits and reasonable cost.  Excellent tuition assistance program
cons: Very low pay; no raises for 3 yrs - then a small increase and no raise this yr.  I was not eligible for 2011 raise and there is no merit increase for employee who finish their one yr time period .  There are internal job opportunties but the process is horribly slow.  You apply to positions which sit there for months unfilled.  Interview for positions and are never contacted again to let you know if you have the position or not (and these are internal candidates).

job_title: Network Security Analyst in Rochester Hills, MI
pros: Vacation Time as within most healthcare industries is good.  Like with most companies, people are generally nice, but some have been there way too long.
cons: If you have the stomach to suck up, then you'll love it!  Otherwise, if you low tolerance for sucking up and looking to be great... then keep it moving.  HFHS has great opportunities for advancement and in regards to the healthcare side things may be a little different, but on the business and IT.. it is totally obsolete and out of whack!

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Clinton Township, MI
pros: Good hourly pay. Not much else.
cons: Ridiculous nurse-patient ratios in the ER. I’ve had anywhere from 8-16 critical patients or 12-17 acute patients. Nights have barely any staff. Most of the nurses working haven’t been nurses for more than a few months or a year. Management does not care about patient safety or nurses’ sanity, they are told repeatedly about the short staffing and nothing is done. In fact more lay-offs happened after we complained. Also, there are barely any techs at all and they don’t even do vitals. The techs are staffed poorly as well so it’s overall just a constant cluster.

review_title: Team-centered work environment excellent but pay decreasing
job_title: Registered Nurse in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Coworkers are great, work flow between disciplines is super, beautiful facility at West Bloomfield
cons: Bonuses being stripped one by one. Midnight bonuses done away with, then weekend cadre bonuses stripped. What's the incentive to work weekends or midnights? Then, hospital spends ridiculous amounts of money on useless things like a greenhouse... Really?

pros: Knowing all the good Henry Ford Hospital does for the community from Wayne to Macomb County.  In the 15 years i was employed at Henry Ford I seen so many good things that the hospital has done not only for employees but for the patients as well. Overall its a great place to work. #ILOVEHENRYFORDHEALTHSYSTEM4EVER
cons: raises didnt come as often as I would like but I really cant say this is all bad because i have full health care benefits from my first day until i left Henry Ford

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Canton, MI
pros: CTO bank allows you to take multiple vacations per year
cons: Lowest paid health system in the country. We barely get pay raises and when we do they're no more than a quarter. Management doesn't really listen to us, they enforce things that our patients don't necessarily care for, such as kiosk check ins. Close to in possible to advance in the system.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Detroit, MI
pros:
- Excellent co-workers
- Advanced medical services
- Organization provides care to all in need
cons:
- Parking is a disorganized fiasco from far-away lots and rickety structure to unpredictable shuttle service.  Adds at least an hour (of unpaid time) to the work day.  No grace period to time management system which is used as the primary means of staff discipline.
- Micromanagement.  Zero input from employees tolerated. Employees are treated like pawns on a chess board. 
- Rapid-fire employee turnover and no recognition of those who stick it out.

review_title: Henry Ford Health System-Referring Physician Advocate
job_title: Referring Physician Advocate in Detroit, MI
pros: Co workers are easy people to work with very nice individuals, welcoming, like family almost. Will be able to network.
cons: Parking is not located within walking distance of hospital (unless its in the summer). You must take a shuttle which requires employees to come to work at least 30-45 minutes earlier than start time.

job_title: Patient Sitter in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: I was a patient sitter at Henry Ford West Bloomfield hospital while I was in nursing school and I loved it.  The environment was always clean, supplies were available when needed, I was treated very well by my supervisors, and I enjoyed coming to work.
cons: The nurses and nursing assistants seemed unhappy at times due to high work loads, but that happens everywhere.  I was surprised that the nursing assistants only made $1 more per hour than I did as a sitter; that seemed quite unfair.

pros: Everyone is very nice and will support you. They don’t expect after hours, weekends nor vacation work.
cons: Pay is well below market. The environment is weirdly reminiscent of the late 90s. The culture is inflexible. Forced time off at holidays without pay if not enough time is accrued. Clear divide between non management salary and management. One Ford Place is desperately in need of an update.  Management silos and protectionism. No one is interested in change except for the very top.

job_title: MICU Staff RN in Fenton, MI
pros: Great place to learn in a Level I, teaching environment; especially for nurse pursuing graduate school.  Also great team work and top pay in the state.  Opportunities for overtime as well.
cons: Inner city issues such as heavy traffic at times, parking is free but you will be required to be bused in to the main campus so must allow extra time before your shift, however this typically affects only the day shift staff and is do-able with time management.

job_title: Senior Performance Measurement Analyst in Detroit, MI
pros:
* Work can be interesting if you like data
* Flex-time schedule
* Health care benefits are pretty good
* Having HFHS on a resume definitely is a plus
* There is a lot of diversity
* There are a lot of intelligent co-workers around you. Most have graduate or terminal degrees.
* You self-manage yourself, meaning you get out what you put into your work.Deadlines are pretty flexible and most stakeholders are understanding
* You are allocated some time each week for personal projects, if you want to go that route
* Management is supportive of most initiatives that you might be interested in pursuing and will try to get you involved in work with other sections of the company, where possible
cons:
* Management: Super nice, but somewhat lacking capability. At least, that was the experience in my department.
* Management: Will say anything to get you in the door, but then will hand off "subpar" work to you without too much guidance.
* Management: Since everyone is overworked, it feels like you never see your direct manager (at least, that was my experience) or, if you do, you're on limited time since they have a ton of work to do, as well.
* Raises: These are company-wide events and not based on merit. If you work super hard, great! You'll still say at the same pay level unless you apply for a 
* Promotions: I don't really know how they happen. It doesn't feel like they're necessarily based on performance so much as your time there and interest in getting one.  Why pay more to an employee when they'll be doing the same work anyway?


My experience at the headquarters (One Ford Place):
* Most sections of the building have drab coloring
* Commuting to and from OFP is a pain if you live north of the city
* There's really no restaurants or anything close to the building.
* Not that it matters, because you only get 30 minutes for lunch
* The overall feel of the building doesn't inspire confidence. It feels like the company is going broke, despite building a new cancer center and teaming up with the Pistons. Workers are definitely afterthoughts here.

pros: No pros, this job was terrible, don’t work here
cons: Your leadership doesn’t know anything about this field, no values or mission alignment, communication is non existent, underpaid for experience and knowledge, made to do work that doesn’t have anything to do with your job, made to take on projects that don’t have anything to do with your job, the organizations has no grasp of what this job requires, leaders have very little leadership or work experience.

review_title: Be Cinderella in the home of the evil stepmother
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technologist in Dearborn, MI
pros: Henry Ford Health System pays its employees well and has a very attractiv benefit package. We get five weeks paid time off per year, which can be used as sick or vacation time. The hospital is very clean and well equipped, and keeps current on technology.
cons: It is such a huge system, that management is too far removed from what is happening at ground level. Every change, hire, and improvement takes so much time. The old saying about it being impossible to move the elephant is very true here.

job_title: Office Manager in Sterling Heights, MI
pros: Communication is directed from top. After working for 3 weeks I had breakfast meeting with Director of Community Care Services. He told us his expectations of us. It was a great experience. The Vice President of Optimeyes walks the talk. She is an excellent business woman, who is driven to succeed. She inspires us every day. The Super Vision center I am a manager at is a growing store looking for like minded professionals.
cons: Some of the long standing managers are given more leeway. This is being handled through attrition instead of direct confrontation.

pros: Good Benefits. Good food in the corporate cafeteria. That's about it. Nothing positionve to contribute, except the system is clinically strong and competitve clinically.
cons: Base Salary stagnant. Operations technology laging behind current standards.  No real "premiere talent" in operational areas I have come in contact with.  Everyone seems to have a I dont know and don't care to know attitude, or just clueless to the fact that they should know. Management protects Management and works the rest of us to death or to the point that you have to seek health from a mental health professional.

pros: Had some really great co-workers who cared about each other and were dedicated to giving excellent patient care.  Dynamic clinical environment provides lots of opportunities to learn new skills and work with diverse patient populations.
cons: Organization seems to be trying to cut its way to prosperity.  Took away vacation days, incredibly long pay freeze, suspension of retirement matching along with increasing workload.  Floor management is quite poor even by nursing standards.  Never felt appreciated by management or administration.

review_title: Sleep Center - Research side of things
pros: Depending on which primary investigator you work for, you may have opportunities for getting your name on some publications.  Depending on the research protocol and the number of other (competent) research assistants working on the task, hours can be flexible to accommodate courses or doctor's appointments, etc.  Some primary investigators will pay more if they really want you, but keep in mind that the pay-scale is set by HFHS so there may be a negotiation cap, unless the job title is re-submitted to allow a higher pay scale.
cons: Realistic opportunities for publication exist mostly for research assistants with either no goals (they think you'll stay around longer if they are given a glimmer of hope of being acknowledged) or those wishing to return to school for a PhD in the sciences (because they want to encourage you to eventually work for them as a Post-doc).  Again, though, this is quite primary investigator-dependent.  Be forewarned that there are a handful of wolves in sheep's clothing among your peers, so don't get too overly cushy about your personal life with other research assistants.  Enjoy their company, but don't join it.

pros: Great benefits, longevity, possible room for growth
cons: Pay, hardly any real opportunities for advancement

review_title: OK place. Not recommended for post docs.
pros: Able to interact with clinicians and clinical oriented research staff
cons: Limited resources for training. Long hours of work and sometimes to come to work even if there is statewide weather alert[i.e. snow storm). No money to buy software yet asked to work using a pirated version. There are really rude and mean people works here.

review_title: If you have a strong work ethic and don't mind little opportunity for advancement, Henry Ford is the place for you.
pros: Good benefits; many good people work here; good physicians on staff in all areas of medical care.
cons: Middle management and upper management are paid too much for doing a poor job.  None of them check to see if employees arrive on time; are signing in use time off when they have already come in late or left for the day.   No person in a nonprofit organization should be making a corporate leader's salary.  HFHS leadership are all disconnected and worry more about their national reputations and how many boards they sit on  than how well their managing a health system and providing opportunity and acknowledgment to their employees.  The pompous sobriety of some division and department administrators is staggering which is evident by  the daily gossip between employees.  The favoritism for their personal assistants encourages disproportionate policy and disregard for payroll keeping.  You're treated like an outcast for getting your work done instead of wasting your time gossiping about other employees.  Management encourages the burden on to their employees to get their work done regardless if they're already doing the work of 2 people; and if you fall behind or make a mistake, it is the focus of your entire annual evaluation months later.  You are humored by having co-workers who have no idea what you do all day, and with whom you choose to not gossip with, score you anonymously on your annual evaluation.  Never think that you will be acknowledged for a job well done or look for appreciation when you do something for your administrator.  It is quickly forgotten.  You had better bring doughnuts and brand named coffee to work regularly and be prepared to waste allot of work time to "fit in" with your co-workers, especially in administrative areas.  If you have a strong work ethic and don't mind having a job where your administrator will do everything they can to hold you back, Henry Ford is the place for you.  The pay for administrative support is below average and don't think that you'll make it to average any time soon.

review_title: This place, (especially West Bloomfield) is IMPLODING
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: The medical benefits and access to care...which should be a no brainer actually. Also the "building" at West Bloomfield is beautiful. Tuition reimbursement is a plus, but I hear its a hassle.
cons:
Beauty only goes so far.  After awhile the main street, Henry's café, atrium, Livewell, spa blah blah blah gets OLD when you start looking at your paycheck. HFHS has given ONE meager 2% raise in 5 years. Jobs are being cut, people are quitting left and right and new people are not hired. They just tack those responsibilities on to someone else with NO increase in pay, no title change, no atta boy..nothing.  Just do more with nothing in return.

I left HFHS for a company with a poor culture reputation BUT double in my salary. I mean I am doing less than I was doing at HFHS for double (no exaggeration) in money.  Money isn't everything and the culture at my new job is what I expected, BUT I value the fact that I am VALUED and not used for peanuts.  The HFHS system should be ashamed of itself.  If you are in, I would get out.  NO more raises are expected until they finish paying for their multi million dollar records system. Yet, everything around us is going up. Rent, car notes, gas, food...but what you make now...you will make in 2014, 2015 and probably 2016...YOU do the math.

review_title: Used to be good, but getting bad
pros: People are hopeful and positive (this is starting to change though). The culture is such that most people have respect for their co-workers, regardless of educational status of position. People are able to communicate respectfully in all directions, up, down, across. It doesn't matter. Management won't really bother you unless you're not doing what you should be doing. Most people are hardworking.
cons: Health Benefits SUCK!!! You pay high deductibles, co-pays, and premiums, and it's probably going to get worse, which is ok for perfectly healthy people, but people who are sick and have to consistantly go to the doctor are SCREWED!!! They'll all be in the poorhouse. I have seen employees neglect specific duties that place a lot at risk, told on them, and nothing seemingly was done...SCAREY!! The attitudes seem to be passive aggressive, rather than straight forward negative. It's WIERD! If you transfer to another position as a professional, you can't keep your current salary. They make you take a pay cut. Jobs are getting more and more scarce. It's hard to find good jobs to transfer in anymore.

review_title: Solid place to begin a career.
pros: Henry Ford Health System has a great culture of connection and teamwork.  The benefits are comparable with surrounding health systems.
cons: This company seems to have "warm body" syndrome and sometimes people can end up in positions where their skills and demeanor aren't best suited for the company's success.  Less than professional behavior is tolerated which can create a tense and dissatisfying environment.

review_title: It has been a great experience working for HFHS, but not sure HFH-Macomb is right place for me!
job_title: Staff RN in Clinton Township, MI
pros: Friendly management, RSV (retirement) package, commute and  team environment.
cons:
Scheduled templates which does not offer flexible scheduling.
Management requires staff to find own coverage to cover weekend off requests. If coverage not found, CTO is denied even if it involves vacation request. 
RN's opinions are not valued by middle management regarding safe nurse/patient ratios

pros: Health insurance, and receive lots of vacation hours
cons: Low salaries, have to punch a time clock, executives only care about themselves, don't have the tools needed to complete assignments and the buildings need remodeling.  Only receive promotions if you "know" someone.  No diversity in upper management.

review_title: Micromanagement of staff by leadership that is focused on itself.
pros: You will not work as hard as you do in private practice. There is a pension plan, a good self-insurance professional liability program and there are reasonable allowances for CME activity.
cons: You will be micromanaged and not allowed to advance your career. You will feel like you are constantly being watched and if you stand out in any way you will come under attack. Those who are good at what they do are seen as threats to incompetent leadership and they will be suppressed. Pay is poor in comparison to market rates, especially in surgical disciplines.

pros: Flex time, benefit and its a job. Good team. Could be better, they've taken out a lot of perks from when j remember. Not good at all
cons: No raises, cultural company has "it's not my job, I don't care- I hear that all the time, and it is sad. Company can be on top if the owner shows appreciate and gratitude towards the employees.

pros: Great health system to be apart of. So many innovative ideas comes out of Henry ford. Lots of projects and growth.
cons: Working in the population health department wasn't great. Made many promises and couldn't keep them. They reward bad behavior and let go strong employees. If you are looking to make a lot of money I wouldn't recommend Henry ford. Great for growth, bad for monetary purposes

review_title: Sad for wasting so much time...
pros: People you work with, friends that have been made.  Schedule flexibility. Benefit options. voluntary benefit options. corporate responsibility footprint.
cons: Low rate of pay, low employee moral, thankless corporate feel. Inability to progress up the ladder.  inaccessibility to growth opportunities.  Lack of  experience being considered in combination with education for new positions. Everything is black and white, past experience is not considered when considering someone for next position in progression on climb up the corporate ladder. Favortism, nepotism, clique-like environment.

review_title: The best place I work right now.
job_title: Biomedical Equipment Technician in Detroit, MI
pros: My co-workers are great, some of the best I have worked with.  There is a heavy emphasis on training at HFHS.  I truly like the fast paced world of a large hospital, there is never a dull minute at the hospital.
cons: The pay is subpar even compared to other hospitals in the area.  There is a huge lack of upper management support.  We are unable to find quality applicants for open positions.

pros: It was close to home.
cons: Employees are not told what is expected of them as to production. Pressure is to perform quickly.  ER management did not know what they were doing in Registration.  They kept changing things around so that registering patients was difficult.  Their concern was only about money and how many patients they could register in the shortest amount of time not caring how long patients were made to wait once they were registered. Atmosphere was like a crazy house. Employees were constantly in fear sitting on nails and afraid for their jobs.  Management was too concerned about petty things going on among employee disagreements.

job_title: Secretary II in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Benefits and you get to meet good people and take classes to make you better at your job.
cons: Some of the Doctors treat you like crap and will even yell at you. I felt like I had to compete for my job a lot.  I was worried the nurse leader was going to go postal.

review_title: Probably the worst hospital job I've had
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Pay, most coworkers, brand new hospital when I started
cons:
Discipline for infractions of rules only applied to certain employees.  Manager showed favoritism to employees in her age group and older, senior staff were treated differently and unfairly. Young manager got promoted rather quickly and went on an ego trip and thrived on department drama.
6 out 13 support staff quit in the first 2 years hospital was opened. What does that tell you?  Didn't like employees who had FMLA...direct quote from managers.

pros: Best coworkers, make your own schedule, almost never miss a lunch.
cons: VERY unsafe patient ratios, high turnover

pros: flexibility- I work for the best choice program- great manager but one lady is totally unprofessional on the phone- its only one really bad seed. I do not understand why they keep her. The rest of the stuff is awesome
cons: none- I cannot think of any- most units are well run and the system is well streamlined and you do not have to guess your next step

pros: You and your work matter at Henry Ford.  There is a job here for anyone and everyone who can get in the door.
cons: Sometimes managers are control freaks and change up everything.  Then coperate will defend their actions.  Being a 24 /7 operation means there is a chance you might get the graveyard shift.

review_title: Low pay, little management support for growth
pros:
Great people, especially with peers and team members 
I have faith in the executive management to change the culture.
cons:
Management support is nearly non existent from Director level people. While I think the VPs and above are great as well as the managers & senior managers, the lower executives are more interested in perception and not the growth of their teams. 

Pay was at least 15-20% below the market value with similar positions.

pros:
Tuition Reimbursement 
Work/ Life Balance
AT&T Services Discount
cons:
Too many bosses, not enough leaders
Not promotion based
Too many "family & friends" departments where you have to know someone to get in
Weak Raises
Hard to find a good mentor
Pay is below market
If you're hourly in a business unit- good luck getting OT approved!

pros: Excellent benefits is only thing I can think of really. Some good workers others act very ghetto  they are lazy and refuse to do their job.
cons: Some good workers others act very ghetto  they are lazy and refuse to do their job. Sleep all night on shifts. And foul language mgt doesn't care your a body they use you up n toss you away.

job_title: Associate General Counsel in Detroit, MI
pros: Good salary and benefits. Generally, an employee - friendly workplace. HFHS' best feature is its foremost principles of care and  concern for patients' health (at HAP, it is care for insurance enrollees).
cons: Overly bureaucratic Human Resources function with poor functioning in most departments, paricularly  hiring and recruitment.

review_title: We were all hoping that becoming part of Henry Ford Health systems would improve working conditions.
pros: Nothing, same old management team. They couldn't care less about staff. You have the feeling they hate us because we work there!
cons: You name it. No work /life balance. Pay is just OK. Benefits are not that good. People on Medicade have better medical coverage. You hardly ever get vacation approved unless you are friends with someone in management or in management. Self scheduling is a total joke. They put you on the days they want no matter what your circumstance.

pros: collegial atmosphere, great people, high tech,clean, good food, convenient pharmacy, friendly staff, pay is good, inexpensive health plans, great deals on glasses
cons: parking is annoying; Detroit is coming back, but isn't the best yet, patient population isnt very educated or compliant or well-off so makes treatment and follow up a challenge

job_title: Critical Care RN in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Not many. I am struggling to find any. Big system maybe?
cons: Run as fast as you can. The pay is the lowest in our industry, and we rarely get raises. The management is terrible, and have horrible communication skills. They make mistakes all the time and blame it on their staff. The customer service scores are TERRIBLE as well, and doctor communication is terrible. Everyone I know is unhappy and looking for a new job ASAP. West Bloomfield is the worst, and the senior leadership team  (including CEO) are incompetent and need to GO. I can't wait to find a new job.

job_title: Critical Care RN in Detroit, MI
pros: Good coworkers, managers, and physicians.
cons: CTO is accrued  hourly at different rates according to longevity with the health system.   Lowest level is approximately 6 hrs for 72 hours worked. The problem is that if you work overtime,you stop accruing CTO at 40 hrs per week. So working overtime does not benefit you as far as increasing CTO. You also don't make overtime pay until after 40 hours/week.  So the first four hours of your "overtime shift" are actually straight pay.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: Great health benefits, networking opportunities
cons: low wages, careless middle management.  If you're not a butt-kisser, you won't have many chances to advance in your career.

job_title: Research Project Coordinator in Detroit, MI
pros: Great company. A large health system that really cares about its patients and the local community. Employees are valued.  Salaries are not exceptional but not bad -- about the middle of the pack.  CEO is great.
cons: Raises only every 2-3 years, and only average 2% when they occur.  However, these infrequent modest raises reflect conservative fiscal management.  I'd rather have fewer raises than face frequent rounds of layoffs when financial conditions deteriorate.

pros: I worked at HFHS for 11 years and major changes for the better. Tremendous attempts to promote overall diversity and positive work atmosphere.

review_title: Top heavy, controlling management and destructive IP practices
pros: The front line clinical staff and the physicians are dedicated, experienced and well-trained. You will always get the clinical back-up you need to care for your patients.
cons:
Below market pay for procedural based specialties, especially surgical specialities including neurosurgery, orthopaedics, ENT and urology. An over bearing management style, micromanagement and a general distrust of physicians by non-physician leadership is a serious problem. Even more of a problem is the top down management style chosen by most Department Chairs, most of whom no longer engage in clinical practice themselves. 
For exceptionally skilled clinicians, there are significant barriers to career advancement. Criticism and attempts to change things for the better are met with the response "you are not a team player". Innovation in practice is discouraged and individual accomplishments are simply not recognized. When exceptional work is done, the system will take credit. I watched senior management and Department Chairs steal the ideas and research results of clinicians, putting their own names on those ideas and claiming them as their own. Several years ago HFHS began promoting itself as a "innovative workplace" and hired an "innovations team" to lead management's efforts to promote this. Unfortunately, they focused on enforcing rigid IP policies that have since become a significant barrier to innovation. This has led to the departure of dozens of exceptionally skilled clinical leaders in the past couple of years as innovative people leave to protect themselves and their ideas.
